Fig. 1 CO conversion of SMo/SBA-15 (olive), SNa-Mo/SBA-15 (red), SK-Mo/SBA-15 (black) and SCs-Mo/SBA-15 (blue). Reaction conditions: 0.2MPa,1000h−1 and CO/H2S/H2 =1:5:4. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 1 Fig. 2 COS, CO2, CH3SH and CH4 selectivity of SMo/SBA-15 (olive), SNa-Mo/SBA-15 (red), SK-Mo/SBA-15 (black) and SCs-Mo/SBA-15 (blue). Reaction conditions: 0.2MPa,1000h−1 and CO/H2S/H2 =1:5:4. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 2 Fig. 3 The CH3SH selectivity of K-Mo/SBA-15 in pre-sulfurdation progress (553K, CO/H2S/H2 =1:5:4, 1000h−1,6h). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 XRD diffractograms of (A) SMo/SBA-15 (olive), SNa-Mo/SBA-15 (red), SK-Mo/SBA-15 (black) and SCs-Mo/SBA-15 (blue).and (B) UMo/SBA-15 (olive), UNa-Mo/SBA-15 (red), UK-Mo/SBA-15 (black) and UCs-Mo/SBA-15 (blue). The crystalline phases detected are Na2SO4(*), K2SO4(●), and MoS2(○). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Raman spectra of SMo/SBA-15 (olive), SNa-Mo/SBA-15 (red), SK-Mo/SBA-15 (black) and SCs-Mo/SBA-15 (blue) catalysts. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 5 Fig. 6 TEM image of SK-Mo/SBA-15. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 XPS S 2p spectra of SNa-Mo/SBA-15 (a), SK-Mo/SBA-15 (b), SCs-Mo/SBA-15 (c) and SMo/SBA-15(d),and UNa-Mo/SBA-15 (e), UK-Mo/SBA-15 (f), UCs-Mo/SBA-15 (g) and UMo/SBA-15(h),catalysts. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 XPS Mo 3d spectra of SNa-Mo/SBA-15 (a), SK-Mo/SBA-15 (b), SCs-Mo/SBA-15 (c) and SMo/SBA-15(d),and UNa-Mo/SBA-15 (e), UK-Mo/SBA-15 (f), UCs-Mo/SBA-15 (g)and UMo/SBA-15(h),catalysts. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 The relationship of CH3SH selectivity as a function of relative atomic percentage of MoIV(S) at 548K. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 NO-TPD of SNa-Mo/SBA-15 (a), SK-Mo/SBA-15 (b), and SCs-Mo/SBA-15 (c). Fig. 10 Fig. 11 The relationship of CH3SH selectivity as a function of concentration of Mo-CUS at 548K. Fig. 11 Table 1 the calculated equilibrium constants of reaction for the CO consume reaction at different temperature. Table 1 Reaction Kp 523K 548K 573K 598K 623K 648K 673K CO+H2S→COS+H2 9.53E-002 8.73 E-002 8.08 E-002 7.54 E-002 7.09 E-002 6.72 E-002 6.40 E-002 Table 2 CO conversion and the distribution of products over various catalysts for thesynthesis of methanethiol from H2S-rich syngas. Table 3 Textural characteristics of SBA-15, Mo/SBA-15, K-Mo/SBA-15, Na-Mo/SBA-15 and Cs-Mo/SBA-15. Table 3 Samples SBET (m2g−1) a VP (cm3g−1) b DP (nm) c SBA-15 1022 1.11 4.9 Mo/SBA-15 366 0.63 6.5 Na-Mo/SBA-15 116 0.24 3.8 K-Mo/SBA-15 68 0.14 3.8 Cs-Mo/SBA-15 52 0.17 3.8 a SBET, BET surface area. b VP, pore volume. c D, average pore diameter. Table 4 The relative Atom% of S Species in sulfided and used Catalysts. Editor’s choice paper The effect of alkali metals on the synthesis of methanethiol from CO/H2/H2S mixtures on the SBA-15 supported Mo-based catalysts Pan Liu a Jichang Lu a Zhizhi Xu a Feng Liu a Dingkai Chen a Jie Yu a Jiangping Liu a Sufang He b Gengping Wan c Yongming Luo a ⁎ a Faculty of Environmental Science and Engineering, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming 650500, PR China Faculty of Environmental Science and Engineering Kunming University of Science and Technology Kunming 650500 PR China b Research Center for Analysis and Measurement, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming 650093, PR China Research Center for Analysis and Measurement Kunming University of Science and Technology Kunming 650093 PR China c Research Center for Analysis and Measurement, Hainan University, Haikou 570100, PR China Research Center for Analysis and Measurement Hainan University Haikou 570100 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The effects of alkali promoters on catalytic behaviors for synthesizing CH3SH over Mo-based catalysts were investigated. The selectivity of CH3SH for Na, K, Cs and non-alkali promoted catalysts are following in the order of Cs-Mo/SBA–15> K-Mo/SBA–15> Na-Mo/SBA–15> Mo/SBA-15. The addition of alkali metals dramatically improved the CH3SH selectivity and CO conversion. The highest selectivity of CH3SH was 66% obtained by incorporating Cs into Mo/SBA-15 which was superior to those reported in the current literature. Based on N2 adsorption-desorption, XRD, Raman, XPS and NO-TPD characterizations, active MoS2 species on oxidized Mo O-S species, obtained from the sulfidation temperature as low as 553K, was considered as active sites for synthesizing CH3SH. And it deemed that the different alkali metals (Na, K, Cs) could give rise to the difference in the sulfidation degree of Mo oxidized species and modify the chemical and electronic environment of the active sites, which resulted in the generation of distinguished concentration of Mo containing coordinatively unsaturated sites (Mo-CUS). Those concentrations of Mo-CUS were detected by NO-TPD to be 161, 210 and 222μmol/g, respectively, which had a positive relationship with the selectivity of CH3SH. Keywords Methanethiol synthesis Molybdenum disulfide Alkali metals Sulfidation degree 1 Introduction Methanethiol is a significant chemical intermediate extensively applied for the production of pharmaceuticals, pesticides, petrochemicals, especially, methionine, an amino acid used as an animal feed supplement. The demand for CH3SH has been growing extensively with the rapid increase in the requirement for methionine over the past decades. Therefore, the synthesis of methanethiol has been the subject of several studies, and the production of high-performance catalysts and knowledge of alternative routes have been explored. At present, the methods for the production of methanethiol mainly include the thiolation reaction of methanol and hydrogen sulfide [1], the gas-phase synthesis from H2S-containing syngas [2], the demethiolation of sulfur-containing amino acids by bacteria [3], the reaction of thiourea or sodium hydrosulfide with dimethyl sulfate [4] and so on. Among these, the thiolation of methanol and hydrogen sulfide is a conventional and relative commercial process because of the high rate of production [5]. However, methanol needs to be firstly produced by carbon monoxide and hydrogen (i.e. synthesis gas) over molybdenum-based catalysts [6], causing enormous resources and energy wasting. The gas-phase reaction, recently, employing H2S-containing syngas (CO/H2) as raw material for synthesizing methanethiol has received considerable attention due to the low-cost and wide-range sources of synthesis gas (CO/H2) and acid gas (H2S) [7–10]. For this synthetic reaction, alkali-promoted Mo-based materials were widely used as effective active catalysts [11–13]. Silicon based and aluminium based oxides, in general, were selected as supports for loading and dispersing molybdenum-containing active phase components. However, the low catalytic activity obtained from alkali-promoted Mo-based catalyst supported on SiO2 suggests that the acidity and basicity of support would not be the main factor to determine catalytic performance. And its intrinsic low surface area together with irregular pore structure probably restrains the improvement in catalytic performance. Therefore, the ordered mesoporous molecular sieves materials with large surface area and regular channel framework might be considered as an option to improve the dispersion of active phases so as to produce more active sites. SBA-15, in the present paper, was selected as the support of catalyst, and the corresponding catalyst exhibited the relative higher catalytic performance in comparison with the catalyst supported on SiO2. Although the support SBA-15 could influence indirectly the catalytic performance of Mo-based catalyst, the active phases and promoters on the support seem to play more important role in the catalytic performance for synthesis of methanethiol. Alkali metals are, among them, frequently selected to introduce into catalysts as additives mainly due to their significant improvement of catalytic activity, selectivity and durability via the modification of surface electron density of alkali-promoted metal or electrostatic interactions associated with alkali-metal ions to change the chemisorptive characteristics of catalyst surface [14,15]. Currently, a few fundamental studies focusing on the area of the alkane oxidation [16,17], CO2 hydrogenation [18], water-gas shift reaction [19], higher-alcohol synthesis [20] have investigated the effect of alkali promoters on catalytic performance. Nevertheless, the investigation of the influence of alkali metals on catalytic performance for this reaction of methanethiol synthesis is less reported [21]. In order to further investigate the cause of high catalytic performance of methanethiol synthesis, we analyzed the catalytic synthesis of methanethiol over Mo-containing catalysts with no alkali addition and three different alkali metal additives (K, Na, Cs) by combining physicochemical characterizations of corresponding catalysts, which involve N2 adsorption-desorption, X-Ray Diffraction (XRD), Raman spectroscopy, Transmission electron microscope (TEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and NO- temperature programmed desorption (NO-TPD) with detailed activity evaluation measurements. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation SBA-15 was prepared by using nonionic triblock copolymer EO20PO70EO20 (Pluronic P123) and tetraethyl silicate TEOS as the structure-directing agent and silicon source, respectively, in according with our previous literatures [22,23]. All the catalysts were prepared by SBA-15, (NH4)6Mo7O24·6H2O and alkali metal salts via the incipient-wetness impregnation method, and the loading of Mo (based on MoO3) and molar ratios of alkali/Mo were 25wt% and 2/1, respectively. After impregnation, all the samples were dried at 120°C for 24h and subsequently calcined at 400°C for 3h in the air. The samples promoted with K2CO3, Na2CO3, Cs2CO3 are denoted as K-Mo/SBA-15, Na-Mo/SBA-15 and Cs-Mo/SBA-15. 2.2 Catalysts characterization The textural properties were conducted on a Beckman Coulter’s SA3100 automatic analyzer at −196°C. BET surface area of the samples was performed by using BET method according to the data of adsorption branch, and the pore size distribution was calculated by the BJH method by using the data of desorption branch. The sulfided catalysts and the used catalysts were characterized by XRD. A Japanese Rigaka’s D/Max-1200 diffractometer (CuKα-radiation, λ=0.154056nm) operating at 40kV and 30mA was used for recording XRD. The evaluation of the diffractogram was made by MDI Jade 5.0 software to identify the crystalline phases within the catalysts. The sulfide catalysts were characterized by NO-TPD on a homemade apparatus equipped with a highly sensitive TCD detector. As for NO-TPD experiment, 0.1g of catalyst sample was loaded in the reactor. Prior to TPD analysis, the sample was pre-treated at 400°C for 1h under the flow of helium (He) to remove adsorbed water as well as impurities, then cooled down to 30°C, at which nitric oxide (NO) was absorbed by using 30ml/min of high concentration NO for about 0.25h. Weakly bound NO was removed by sweeping with the flow of high purity He at 30°C, and then the temperature was increased to 400°C at a heating rate of 10°C/min under the flow of high purity He. A thermal conduction detector (TCD) was used to detect the desorbed NO. Raman spectrum was carried out by using a Via Reflex Raman spectrometer with 514nm emission line from Ar+ laser at room temperature. TEM images of the catalysts were equipped with a JEM-2100 microscope operated at 200kV. XPS technique was employed to determine the composition and chemical state of different elements composing the solids using a PHI 5000 Versa Probe II with non-monochromatic Al Ka radiation (1486.6eV). CasaXPS software was used to fit the corresponding spectra and charge referencing was detected against adventitious carbon with the C 1s at 284.6eV. 2.3 Catalytic activity test The catalytic activity experiment was carried out in a 6mm i.d. quartz fixed-bed reactor. 0.4g catalyst (40–60mesh) was loaded with quartz wool in the isothermal region of the reactor. Then, the reactant gas (CO/H2S/H2 =1:5:4) was introduced into the reactor under the conditions of P=0.2MPa, GHSV=1000h−1 and under different reaction temperature (523k–673K) and the used catalysts were denoted as UMo/SBA-15, UNa-Mo/SBA-15, UK-Mo/SBA-15 and UCs-Mo/SBA-15. Prior to each activity evaluation measurements, all of the samples were presulfided in the gas stream with CO/H2S/H2 =1:5:4 (20ml/min) at 553K for 6h, the catalysts after sulfidation were denoted as SMo/SBA-15, SNa-Mo/SBA-15, SK-Mo/SBA-15 and SCs-Mo/SBA-15. Reactor products were online detected using three GC fitted with one flame ionization detector (FID), two flame photometric detectors (FPD) and two thermal conductivity detectors (TCD). Carbon hydrogen components including CH3SH, CH4, little C2H4 and C2H6 were detected by FID with a porapak Q column. The FPD equipping with a HP-Plot/Q capillary column was employed to detect sulfur-containing matters including COS, CS2, CH3SH and H2S. TCD equipped with TDX-01 carbon molecular sieve was used to detect H2, CO and CO2. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The catalytic activity test CO conversions of SMo/SBA-15, SNa-Mo/SBA-15, SK-Mo/SBA-15 and SCs-Mo/SBA-15 are displayed in Fig. 1 . It is observed that CO conversion of four catalysts (SMo/SBA-15, SNa-Mo/SBA-15, SK-Mo/SBA-15 and SCs-Mo/SBA-15) is distinguishing. The CO conversion of Mo/SBA-15 is a little higher than SNa-Mo/SBA-15 and SCs-Mo/SBA-15 during 523K to 548K, but the CO conversion of SMo/SBA-15 is decreasing with the temperature rising. On the whole, SK-Mo/SBA-15 exhibits the highest CO conversion while the lowest CO conversion is observed for SMo/SBA-15. For the SK-Mo/SBA-15, CO conversion increases with the increasing reaction temperature and the maximum CO conversion is achieved at 598K. Further increasing reaction temperature results in the decline in the CO conversion. Table 1 shows the equilibrium constant of CO consumption reaction (CO+H2S→COS+H2), it can be seen that the equilibrium constant is decreasing with the temperature increasing which suggests rising temperature is not benefited to the occurrence of CO consumed reaction. Therefore, the reason for the decreasing CO conversion at high temperature is originated from equilibrium limitations. The conversion of CO is generally in following order: SK-Mo/SBA–15> SCs-Mo/SBA–15> SNa-Mo/SBA-15> SMo/SBA-15. The selectivities of COS, CH3SH, CO2 and CH4 over SMo/SBA-15, SNa-Mo/SBA-15, SK-Mo/SBA-15 and SCs-Mo/SBA-15 are presented in Fig. 2 (A–D). It can be seen that the selectivity of COS for SMo/SBA-15 reaches up to 99% indicating that COS is the main product. There is no CH3SH generated but a trace of CH4 was detected in system. After the doping of alkali metals, the selectivity toward COS has decreased, on the contrary, the selectivity of other products has increased, which suggests that COS is further consumed and converted to other species in alkali metals added catalysts. The selectivity toward COS (shown in Fig. 2A) over SK-Mo/SBA-15 decreases slightly with increasing the reaction temperature, and the minimum value is reached at 598K, and then raises slightly with the reaction temperature increasing. The selectivity of COS over SCs-Mo/SBA-15 is similar with that of SK-Mo/SBA-15 during the entire reaction temperature range. The highest selectivity of COS for three alkali metals doped catalysts is observed for SNa-Mo/SBA-15. As the reaction temperature increasing from 523K to 648K, the selectivity of COS decreases obviously from 60% to 10%, afterwards, increases slightly. The selectivity of CH3SH of four catalysts is presented in Fig. 2B. There is no CH3SH produced over SMo/SBA-15, for these alkali metals promoted catalysts, the SK-Mo/SBA-15 and SCs-Mo/SBA-15 exhibit relatively higher CH3SH selectivity compared to SNa-Mo/SBA-15. Table 2 shows the product distribution and catalyst activity of some reported catalysts [8,35] for the synthesis of methanethiol from H2S-rich syngas. The maximum selectivity of CH3SH is observed for SCs-Mo/SBA-15 (66.5%) at 598K which is higher than other catalysts. However, the corresponding selectivity declines with further increasing reaction temperature. It is noteworthy that the CH4 selectivity of SNa-Mo/SBA-15(shown in Fig. 2D) is far higher than SK-Mo/SBA-15 and SCs-Mo/SBA-15, which indicates the conversion of a large amount of CH3SH into CH4. In order to observe the catalyst activity at the initial stage of the reaction, the pre-sulfured progress and the next 3h catalyst activity change for fresh K-Mo/SBA-15 were measured, and the result was shown in Fig. 3 . The CH3SH selectivity gradually increases as time goes on, which can attribute to the increase of the amount of active site. To understand the difference in the catalytic activities among these four catalysts (SMo/SBA-15, SK-Mo/SBA-15, SNa-Mo/SBA-15 and SCs-Mo/SBA-15), N2 adsorption-desorptionand XRD as well as TPD were employed to characterize them in the following sections. 3.2 Textural properties of the catalysts The textural properties of support and the catalyst samples are tabulated in Table 3 . The parent SBA-15 exhibits high BET surface area (1022m2g−1), pore volume (1.11cm3g−1) and average pore diameter (4.3nm). Compared with SBA-15, the supported catalysts show a great decrease both in specific surface area and pore volume, which should be attributed to the blockage of some pores during incorporating SBA-15 with 25wt% of Mo as well as the corresponding alkali metals [20]. The decrease in the corresponding pore diameter and pore volume confirms this point. It is observed that the order of surface area is as followed: Mo/SBA–15> Na-Mo/SBA–15> K-Mo/SBA–15> Cs-Mo/SBA-15, which is mismatch with the catalytic activity order: Mo/SBA–15< Na-Mo/SBA–15< Cs-Mo/SBA–15< K-Mo/SBA-15. Therefore, it can be concluded that surface area does not play a key role in determining catalytic performances for synthesizing CH3SH. 3.3 X-ray diffraction measurements X-ray diffraction patterns of the sulfided catalysts and the corresponding used catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 (A) and (B), respectively. It can be seen from Fig. 4(A) that the XRD peaks of the sample SMo/SBA-15 appear at 2θ = 14.33, 33.38 and 58.19°, which are attributed to MoS2 phase (PDF#24-0513), but the intensity of diffraction peaks is relatively low. As for SK-Mo/SBA-15, the dominant diffraction peaks is ascribed to K2SO4 (PDF#05-0613). According to the related literature, the K2SO4 species was possibly obtained via the intermediate of K2MoS4 and K2S on the activity evaluation process, where K2S reacted readily and irreversibly with water, thus leading finally to the agglomerated K2SO4 phase under the reaction conditions [24]. The similar signals attributed to Na2SO4 (PDF#37-1465) is observed over Na-Mo/SBA-15. In addition to the broad diffraction peak originated from parent SBA-15, there are almost no crystalline signals found over sulfured Cs-Mo/SBA-15. It is noted that the intensity of MoS2 phase was relatively low in the XRD patterns of all the four sulfured catalysts. This is possible that the Mo-containing species exists as amorphous phase or the small sized domains with high dispersion on the surface of SBA-15, that is hard to be detected [25,26]. After reaction, the MoS2 phase (PDF#24-0513) is detected in the XRD patterns of all the four catalysts which indicates the conversion of amorphous or small-sized MoS2 species into crystalline or large-sized MoS2 phase during the process in the flow of CO/H2/H2S. It is interesting that the CH3SH selectivity over SK-Mo/SBA-15 and SCs-Mo/SBA-15 has no distinct difference between 543K and 648K. It suggests that crystalline properties and the particle size of MoS2 species have no relationship with the selectivity of CH3SH. 3.4 Raman spectroscopy & TEM Fig. 5 shows the Raman spectra of SMo/SBA-15, SK-Mo/SBA-15, SNa-Mo/SBA-15 and SCs-Mo/SBA-15 catalysts. Three main lines at 382, 408, and 450cm−1 can be observed in all four spectrums, which are attributed to the Mo-S stretching mode along the basal plane, S-Mo-S stretching mode along to the C-axis and the second-order scattering of the MoS2 phase, respectively [27,28].According to the existing research, the structure of observed species has been identified as the MoS2. The widths of the bands at 219, 289 and 336cm−1 suggest the presence of MoO3 [24], and peaks’ intensity on SMo/SBA-15 is higher than alkali promoted catalysts, indicating that the existence of alkali metal may lead to the easier reduction of MoO3 phase. TEM image of K-Mo/SBA-15 is presented in Fig. 6 , it can be seen that the stacked (002) planes of MoS2 phase with d002 =0.65nm presented. 3.5 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy XPS analyses were carried out in order to obtain information about the oxidation state and dispersion of the different elements on the catalyst surface. Figs. 7 and 8 show the spectra of S 2p and Mo 3d-S 2s region of the sulfured and used Mo/SBA-15, Na-Mo/SBA-15, K-Mo/SBA-15, Cs-Mo/SBA-15 catalysts. In order to get more details information about catalyst, all the XPS spectra were carefully decomposed. In all samples, Mo and S coexist which leads to the overlapping of both Mo 3d and S 2s BE regions. Therefore, the contribution of S 2p must be firstly ruled out, and then the corresponding S 2s peaks can be deduced easily through the relationship between S 2p and S 2s orbit, the true contribution of the Mo 3d level can be obtained in the end. The binding energies (BE), full widths at half-maximum(FWHM), peak areas of S 2p, S 2s, and Mo 3d contributions were calculated by the literature reported by A. Cordova at al [29]. As for SK-Mo/SBA-15, the decomposition region of S 2p spectra is presented in Fig. 7b. Three S doublets located at 162.2, 163.7, 169.3eV are decomposed in a satisfactory way. The first component at about 162.2eV has been assigned to S2− species presented in MoS2. The second contribution at about 169.2eV can be attributed to the presence of sulfate species S6+(SO4 2−) [30], the binding energy at around 163.7eV can be assigned to disulfide bridges (S-S)2− phase which will inhibit the formation of the Mo−S−K phase [29], so as the Mo−S−Na and Mo−S−Cs phase. The spectrum of UK-Mo/SBA-15 (Fig. 5f) is similar with the sulfided catalyst. With respect to Na-Mo/SBA-15 catalyst (Fig. 7a and e), an obviously variation on full widths at half-maximum (FWHM) attributed to MoS2 phase was observed for S 2p3/2 at 162eV, which indicates the concentration of MoS2 increased after reaction. The Binding Energy at 163.52eV assigned to disulfide bridges phase whose concentration was decreased after reaction (shown in Fig. 7e), thus indicating the transformation of (S-S)2− in higher temperature. The S 2p spectrum of SCs-Mo/SBA15 was overlapped with Cs 4p BE regions, thus, the Cs 4p was decomposed and removed from S 2p spectrum. The revised XPS spectrum of the S 2p core level of SCs-Mo/SBA-15 is shown in Fig. 7c. The contribution located at 161.9eV is assigned to the MoS2 phase. The relative atomic percent (%Si) of each element is summarized in Table 4 . It can be seen that the relative atomic percents of (S-S)2− phase in SMo/SBA-15, SK-Mo/SBA-15, SNa-Mo/SBA-15 and SCs-Mo/SBA-15 are 23.62%, 9.46%, 16.47%, 12.88%, respectively, indicating the catalyst with alkali added can decrease the amount of disulfide bridges. The Mo 3d spectra of four samples were decomposed, Fig. 8 shows the spectra of the Mo 3d−S 2s region of the sulfured and used Mo/SBA-15, Na-Mo/SBA-15, K-Mo/SBA-15, Cs-Mo/SBA-15 catalysts, and the relative atomic percent is tabulated in Table 5 . The contributions at 229.4eV, 230.0 and 233.17 for SK-Mo/SBA-15 and UK-Mo/SBA-15 sample have been attributed to Mo 3d5/2 components of MoIV, MoV and MoVI, respectively. Among them, the first contribution has been ascribed to the MoS2 phase, and the second contribution has been assigned to the MoV surrounded by oxygen and sulfur atoms (intermediate sulfidation phase, denoted MoV-OS), and the contribution at higher binding energy is generally related to oxidized MoVI species (denoted as MoVI-O) [29]. The atom% of MoVI-O decreased after reaction accompanied with the increase percentage of MoV-OS, which indicates more MoO3 was sulfided and converted into intermediate and MoS2 phase during reaction process with increasing temperature from 553K to 673K. The same phenomenon is also observed for SNa-Mo/SBA-15, whose atom percentage of MoVI-O is obviously higher than SK-Mo/SBA-15 and SCs-Mo/SBA15, and the MoS2 phase (active phase of producing CH3SH) over SNa-Mo/SBA-15 is only 39.00%, which explains why the catalytic activity of SNa-Mo/SBA-15 is lower than that of other two catalysts. As for Cs-Mo/SBA-15, the contribution of 228.5eV attributed to MoS2 on sulfured and used catalysts were observed, which is a little bit lower than it within Na-Mo/SBA-15 and K-Mo/SBA-15. This phenomenon that binding energy shift to lower value was because that the Cs atom have stronger electronic donate ability than K and Na. Moreover, the atom percentage of MoV(O) phase for all these four catalysts decreased after reaction, thus indicating the conversion Mo-O phase into Mo-S phase during reaction process (553K∼673K). The existed of MoS2, the sulfided intermediate phase can be deduced according to S 2p and Mo 3d spectra. The MoS2 can be identified by the coexistence of S 2p3/2 peak at the region of 161.7 eV-162.6eV and Mo 3d5/2 component at the region of 229.4±0.2eV. Meanwhile, the sulfided intermediate phase can be confirmed by concurrence of the S 2p3/2 peak at the region of 161.7 eV-162.6eV and Mo 3d5/2 at the region of 229.6-230.8eV. Moreover, the difference in relative atomic percentage of MoVI(S) species for SMo/SBA-15, SNa-Mo/SBA-15, SCs-Mo/SBA-15 and SK-Mo/SBA-15 (46.08%, 39.00%, 63.5%, 57.92%) indicates that the sulfidation degree of Mo species is improved when K and Cs are added, and the sulfidation degree of Mo species for different alkali metal promoted catalysts are significantly different, in which the sulfidation degree of them is followed the order: SNa-Mo/SBA–15< SMo/SBA–15< SCs-Mo/SBA–15< SK-Mo/SBA-15. After the activity test, it is found that there is difference in the relative atomic percentage of MoIV(S) between catalysts before and after reaction. It indicates that more MoS2 species obtained during higher sulfidation temperature. Moreover, the sulfidation degree of used catalysts followed the order: SMo/SBA–15< S Na-Mo/SBA–15< SCs-Mo/SBA–15< SK-Mo/SBA-15, means Na can improve sulfidation degree only in higher sulfured temperature. Actually, the MoS2 phase has been considered as active sites for synthesizing CH3SH. To determine the influence of the sulfidation degree on the catalytic performance, the relationship of CH3SH selectivity as a function of relative atomic percentage of MoIV(S) at 548K is established and displayed in Fig. 9 . It can be seen that selectivity of CH3SH has the positive relationship with amount of sulfided MoIV(S) species, which suggests that the sulfidation degree is one of the important factors to determine the catalytic performance. 3.6 NO- temperature programmed desorption According to the literature, the MoS2 phase has coordinatively unsaturated sites (CUS) at the perimeter of the (1 0 1 0) plane, which acts as active sites in hydrogenolysis and hydrogenation reactions [31–33]. NO is often used as a probe molecule to measure the concentration of CUS because it can adsorb on CUS at room temperature and form Mo(NO)2, an unstable complexes, which can be outgassed from room temperature to 673K [34].Thus, the NO-TPD was carried out and the result is shown in Fig. 10 . As can be seen, a big desorption peak is observed below 673K, which has been regarded as the desorption of NO adsorbed on Mo-CUS. The small shoulder peak was observed on SKMo/SBA-15, resulting from the interaction between K and Mo. Moreover, the position of adsorption peak is obviously difference among SNa-Mo/SBA-15, SK-Mo/SBA-15 and SCs-Mo/SBA-15, the corresponding desorption temperature of them is in the following order: TCs-Mo/SBA–15 < K-Mo/SBA–15 < Na-Mo/SBA-15. The density of CUS is obtained from the area of desorption peak, and the CUS density values of SNa-Mo/SBA-15, SK-Mo/SBA-15 and SCs-Mo/SBA-15 are calculated to be 161, 210 and 222μmol/g, respectively. Combining with the activity results, the relationship of CH3SH selectivity as a function of Mo-CUS concentration is presented in Fig. 11 . It is found that the well correlation coefficient is obtained; thus suggesting that the selectivity of CH3SH is closely related to concentration of Mo-CUS. Those Mo-CUS could nondissociatively adsorb the CO molecule and dissociatively adsorb the H2 and H2S molecule, thus facilitating the reaction of CO with H2S to COS (confirmed by the activity result that Mo/SBA-15 only with Mo-CUS have the 100% selectivity toward COS). Meanwhile, alkali metals could act as the basic sites and an electron donor which enhances the chemisorption of electron acceptor species, such as COS, and can be in favor of stabilizing the bond of C-S. Therefore, the direct or indirect hydrogenation of COS leads to the production of CH3SH. Oliver Y et al. [24] found that the presence of K+ in MoS2 phase drastically increases the selectivity to CO2, CS2, and CH3SH and reduces the selectivity to COS, the disproportionation of COS and the consecutive hydrogenation of CS2 and formed CH3SH is catalyzed on the K+-decorated MoS2 phase. The exist of K+ can modify the chemical and electronic environment of the active sites, thus the alkali decorated Mo-CUS is deemed to be the activity sites. According to the analysis results of XPS, when those alkali metal promoted MoS2 samples were sulfided at same low temperature, alkali metal (Na, K, Cs) could give rise to the difference in the sulfidation degree of Mo species and modify the chemical and electronic environment of active sites, which leads to the generation of distinguished CUS concentration and then selectivity of CH3SH. 4 Conclusion The influences of alkali promoters (Na, K and Cs) on the conversion of CO and the selectivity of CH3SH, COS, CO2 and CH4 over SBA-15 supported Mo based catalysts were investigated and compared. The selectivities of CH3SH for non-alkali promoted catalyst and Na, K, Cs promoted catalysts are in the order of K-Mo/SBA–15> Cs-Mo/SBA-15> Na-Mo/SBA–15> Mo/SBA-15. Considering experimental data, the addition of alkali metals improved the CO conversion and CH3SH selectivity, and the difference in the selectivity of CH3SH among these alkalis promoted catalysts was due to the difference in the sulfidation degree. The different alkali metals (Na, K, Cs) could give rise to the difference in the sulfidation degree of Mo oxidized species owing to the different electronic effect of alkali metals, which led to the formation of different concentration of alkali metal promoted Mo-CUS. NO-TPD result showed that those concentrations of Mo-CUS for Na-Mo/SBA-15, K-Mo/SBA-15 and Cs-Mo/SBA-15 are 161, 210 and 222μmol/g, respectively, which should be responsible for the selectivity of CH3SH. coredata.dc:description: The effects of alkali promoters on catalytic behaviors for synthesizing CH3SH over Mo-based catalysts were investigated. The selectivity of CH3SH for Na, K, Cs and non-alkali promoted catalysts are following in the order of Cs-Mo/SBA–15> K-Mo/SBA–15> Na-Mo/SBA–15> Mo/SBA-15. The addition of alkali metals dramatically improved the CH3SH selectivity and CO conversion. The highest selectivity of CH3SH was 66% obtained by incorporating Cs into Mo/SBA-15 which was superior to those reported in the current literature. Based on N2 adsorption-desorption, XRD, Raman, XPS and NO-TPD characterizations, active MoS2 species on oxidized Mo O-S species, obtained from the sulfidation temperature as low as 553K, was considered as active sites for synthesizing CH3SH. And it deemed that the different alkali metals (Na, K, Cs) could give rise to the difference in the sulfidation degree of Mo oxidized species and modify the chemical and electronic environment of the active sites, which resulted in the generation of distinguished concentration of Mo containing coordinatively unsaturated sites (Mo-CUS). Those concentrations of Mo-CUS were detected by NO-TPD to be 161, 210 and 222μmol/g, respectively, which had a positive relationship with the selectivity of CH3SH.
coredata.dc:title: The effect of alkali metals on the synthesis of methanethiol from CO/H2/H2S mixtures on the SBA-15 supported Mo-based catalysts
